title: Component Reusability
subject: React
theory:
## DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself)
The goal of React is to create a library of reusable Lego blocks.

### The `children` Prop
React automatically passes special prop `children` for content nested *inside* your component tag.
`<Card>I am child</Card>` -> `props.children` equals 'I am child'.

### Composition
Instead of Inheritance (creating sub-classes), React prefers Composition (wrapping components).

examples.explanation: FancyBorder doesn't know what's inside it. It just renders {props.children}.

interview_questions.question: Composition vs Inheritance in React?
interview_questions.answer: React recommends Composition. There are very few (if any) cases where component inheritance is needed.

real_world_use_cases.description: <Layout><PageContent /></Layout>. The Layout contains header/footer, and renders children in the middle.

summary: Mastering the children prop opens the door to creating powerful container components.
